STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 27, 2020
Laura Nye
Branch County DHHS
388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
RE: License #: CP120200999
Branch County DHHS
388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
Dear Ms. Nye:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 10/20/20.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and ISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please identify why the previous CAP did not resolve the issue and what
additional action will be implemented to assure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP120200999
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Laura Nye, Administrator
Name of Facility: Branch County DHHS
Facility Address: 388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
Facility Telephone #: (517) 279-4200
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1993
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection:
No onsite completed due to COVID 19. Video conference occurred on 9/30/20 and 10/20/20.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(j) Visitation.
One of six foster care files did not have a foster home visit documented for February
2020 as required by agency policy.
One of six foster care files did not have documentation of a quarterly visit in the
parental home as required by the agency policy.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of six foster care files did not have an updated medical exam as required. The
last medical exam was completed on 6/26/19.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child…
Three of six foster care files were missing documentation to show that foster parents
were provided with required information at placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/7/19 interim review, CAP approved 1/28/19
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4

Two of six foster care files held late service plans.
File one: USP due on 12/24/19 was completed on 12/26/19 (2 days late). USP due
on 6/21/20 was completed on 6/22/20 (1 day late). USP due 9/19/20 completed on
9/21/20 (2 days late).
File two: USP due 6/1/20 was completed 6/20/20 (1 day late).
REPEAT VIOLATION:
10/22/19 renewal review, CAP approved 11/7/19
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
Two of two independent living files did not have monthly budgets or other
documentation to show youth are managing expenditures.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days…
One of two independent living files held a late service plan. The ISP due on 7/25/20,
was not completed until 9/15/20.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of two independent living files did not have IL contracts reviewed and updated
every 90 days.
File one: No IL contracts were on file from October 2019 to present.
File two: No IL contracts were on file from June 2020 to present.
5

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 777-08C Parent agency treatment plan and service agreement
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement…
CI 17-099
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
6

Eight of eight foster care and independent living files were missing required timely
signatures on Parent Agency Treatment Plans.
File one: The 3/12/20 PATP was not signed by the parent until 7/9/20. The 6/20/20
PATP had the caregiver’s signature but it was undated. The 9/20/20 PATP was
missing the parent’s signature.
File two: The 6/20/20 PATP was not signed by the parent until 8/20/20. The 3/13/20
PATP had undated signatures by the parent and foster parent, and did not have a
signature by the other parent. 12/14/19 PATP was signed late by the foster parent
on 3/16/20 and was missing a parent signature.
File three: The 2/4/20 and 4/29/20 PATPs were missing the parents and foster
parent signatures. The 7/28/20 PATP was missing the parent’s signatures.
File four: 1/7/20, 4/3/20, and 7/1/20 PATPs were missing the parent’s signatures.
The 4/3/20 and 7/1/20 PATPs were missing the caregiver’s signature.
File five: The 12/24/19, 3/23/20, and 6/21/20 PATPs were missing the parent and
caregiver signatures.
File six: The 12/12/19, 3/3/20 and 6/1/20 PATPs were missing parent and caregiver
signatures.
File seven: The March, May and August 2020 PATPs were not signed by the youth.
The December 2019 PATP was signed but undated.
File eight: The 9/15/20 PATP was not signed by the youth as of 10/20/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/7/19 interim review, CAP approved 1/28/19
10/22/19 renewal review, CAP approved 11/7/19
FOM 801 Medical passport
Page 11-13
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport containing all items listed in MCL
722.954c.
7

Five of six foster care files were missing Medical Passports as required by policy.
File one: A medical passport was completed in March 2020, an update was due in
June, but was not completed until July.
File two: March, July, August 2020, and November 2019 passports were missing
parent signatures. In addition, passports were not completed quarterly: July 2019,
November 2019, March 2020, August 2020.
File three: 4/17/20 and 6/30/20 passports were created late in MiSACWIS on
10/15/20 and do not have required signatures.
File four: The last medical passport on file is from 7/12/19; missing four updated
passports for the year.
File five: Youth placed on 8/16/19. No medical passports on file until 9/24/20;
missing one initial and four updated passports for the year. No signatures were
obtained.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/7/19 interim review, CAP approved 1/28/19
10/22/19 renewal review, CAP approved 11/7/19
FOM 722-09 Updated service plan
Supervisory approval- prior to finalizing, the USP along with the
required assessments (FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed
and approved by the foster care supervisor only after a face-to-
face meeting with the worker. Case service plan approval
process requires the foster care supervisor to review and
approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the report date.
Two of eight foster care and independent living files held service plans that were
approved beyond the required 14 day time frame.
File one: 12/24/19 USP approved on 1/14/20 (5 days late). 3/23/20 USP approved
on 4/30/20 (24 days late). 9/19/20 USP approved 10/7/20 (2 days late).
File two: 7/28/20 USP approved 8/17/20 (6 days late)
FOM 722-06b Family team meeting
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
8

Three of eight foster care and independent living files did not meet the requirements
of this policy.
File one: A 4/19/20 placement change did not have an accompanying FTM. The
2/18/20 FTM was held outside of the 30 day timeframe for the 4/3/20 USP. An 1105
report was not completed for the 12/21/19, 4/28/20, and 6/30/20 FTMs.
File two: An FTM was not completed prior to the 12/24/19 and 6/21/20 USPs. The
2/5/20 FTM was outside of the required timeframe for the 3/23/20 USP. The 9/15/20
FTM did not have an 1105 report completed.
File three: The 12/2/19 and 2/11/20 FTMs did not have 1105 reports completed. The
4/22/20 FTM was outside of the required timeframe for the 6/1/20 USP, as was the
7/7/20 FTM for the 8/28/20 USP.
REPEAT VIOLTION:
1/7/19 interim review, CAP approved 1/28/19
10/22/19 renewal review, CAP approved 11/7/19
FOM 722-06H Timely entry of caseworker contacts
Page 15-16
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact. All other social work contacts
must be entered prior to the report period end date on the
applicable case service plan.
Several caseworker contacts were entered outside of the require timeframe. Specific
case examples were provided to the agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/7/19 interim review, CAP approved 1/28/19
10/22/19 renewal review, CAP approved 11/7/19
FOM 722-08E Foster Care Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change:
Page 3- Prior to a planned placement change, or within three
business days of an emergency placement change, the
caseworker must document…
Page 6- Within three business days of foster care and/or
juvenile justice program/case closure, the caseworker must
document…
9

Five of eight foster care and independent living files did not have a DHHS-69
completed within the required timeframe.
File one: Youth moved 10/31/19, DHHS-69 completed on 11/8/19.
File two: Youth returned home on 7/2/20, DHHS-69 completed on 10/15/20.
File three: Youth moved on 12/9/19, DHHS-69 not signed or dated although
MISACWIS shows the creation date as 10/20/20. Youth also moved on 4/19/19,
DHHS-69 not signed or dated although MISACWIS shows creation date as
10/20/20.
File four: Youth moved 9/7/20, DHHS-69 completed on 9/23/20.
File five: Youth moved on 6/26/20, DHHS-69 completed on 10/19/20.
Two of two closed foster care files did not have a DHHS-69 completed.
IV. ANALYST REPORT
No safety alerts were reported by the DCWL analyst.
V. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Young Adult Voluntary Foster Care- The agency was reminded that licensing rules
for independent living apply to YAVFC youth. YAVFC is the youth’s legal status,
while IL is the placement and therefore IL rules apply.
VI. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
It was discussed with the agency how they have attempted to meet requirements
during the COVID-19 pandemic, while offices have been closed, and face to face
contacts were limited. The agency continues to implement strategies and were open
to additional suggestions.
VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The CAP, approved 11/7/19, was the result of the 10/22/19 renewal evaluation.
During the current review period the facility was found to have six repeat violations in
the areas of Foster Parent information, Service Plan timeliness, PATP signatures,
10

Medical Passports, FTMs, and timely contract entry. Four of these repeat violations
were also found in the 2018 interim review (report dated 1/7/19, CAP approved
1/28/19). As these areas continue to have violations, a thorough CAP needs to be
developed to address why the previous CAPs did not resolve the issue, and what
new steps will be taken to ensure compliance over the next year. As always, DCWL
is available to provide consultation during CAP development and implementation.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, ISEP requirements, or policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
October 27, 2020
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 16, 2020
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
11
